awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Scale and Performance in Anonymous Communication
awd_abstract_narration: This project targets an important aspect of online privacy by giving users the ability to hide their communication patterns through anonymous communication.  Anonymous communication mitigates the "dossier effect," where third parties can accumulate enough information about users to construct a detailed profile, regardless of the use of encryption.  This project addresses two key research issues in anonymous communication: scale and performance.  To support large user bases, it is necessary to redesign the current centralized architecture of anonymous communication systems and replace it with a peer-to-peer one.  The project studies the myriad security, privacy, and performance issues introduced by such a change.  Better performance will improve the usability of anonymous communication to make it a reasonable option for routine Internet use.  The ultimate goal is to make anonymity technology accessible to all people for appropriate uses and to integrate it into basic Internet protocols.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to develop tools, techniques, and scientific understanding for technologies that enable private online communications. While end-to-end encryption is becoming more widespread, it protects only the contents of communications and not their metadata. Information about what web sites you visit, who you communicate with, and how often, can be used to learn many intimate details about your life, and is readily available to Internet service providers, advertisers, commercial data brokers, governments, and criminals. Anonymous communication networks (ACNs) can help hide this information from prying eyes, but existing technologies introduce significant performance penalties, which impact the usability of the project. They also face challenges as their user base increases as some components grow to become overloaded. Finally, their security and suceptibility to attacks is not fully understood. This project significantly advanced the state of the art in these areas, impacting both the theory and practice of building ACNs.


A primary focus of this project has been the design of scalable ACNs that can grow to many millions of participants. The PI had previously developed a scalable design, called ShadowWalker, but its security properties were difficult to reason about—something that practitioners in the field identified as a significant barrier to technology transfer. During this project, two new scalable designs were developed that were built on simpler assumptions: a cryptographic technique called Private Information Retrieval, and a social communication network that is resilient to adversarial infiltration. These designs can be proven secure under the security of the underlying assumptions and thus are resilient to a large class of attacks.


To better understand the security of ACNs, this project developed a number of new attacks. One attack used side information about network bandwidth to infer how supposedly private communication was routed; another demonstrated that sensors in a smart phone can be used by a website to uniquely identify a device and thus violate its owner's anonymity. Along the course of this project, the information leak attack on decentralized ACNs was extended and refined, showing the breadth of its application to a large class of designs. This attack is now forms a foundation of how security of decentralized ACNs is analyzed. More generally, these attacks help advance the understanding of how secure ACNs should be designed and implemented.


ACNs, by hiding what websites are visited, can help users get around censorship; the response of censors has been to block access to ACNs entirely. This project made significant progress in developing censorship countermeasures, including several options to encode censored traffic in innocuous looking communication, and techniques to get information about secret circumvention proxies into the hands of users, while preventing censors from discovering them. Another contribution has been the design of in-network censorship circumvention infrastructure, now called Decoy Routing, which forms one of the more promising approaches for long-term censorship circumvention, as it is difficult to block without incurring a lot of collateral damage.


Finally, the project considered broader applications of private communications, such as private online conversations. A key new technology, DP5, has shown a way that a collection of central servers can provide presence information—a list of which of one's contacts is online and from where—while preserving a high-level of privacy resilient to even long-term traffic analysis. DP5 has been presented at several academic, industrial, and activist conferences and has contributed to the revitalized interest in metadata-private onlien communications.


Throughout the course of this project, the PI and other project members interacted closely with the community of practitioners and users of ACNs, learning their perspective on important problems, communicating new attacks, and sharing new technologies that were developed in this project, and thus both directly and indirectly influencing the practice of private communications. The project also involved a number of graduate and undergraduate researchers in an integral way, çontributing to their education and leading to several PhD theses.
